nb.purpose: Brukes som en generisk seksjonsoverskrift som skal gis nytt navn i en templat for å passe i en gitt klinisk kontekst.
nb.use: Brukes til å lage en seksjonsoverskrift i en templat, hvis navn deretter endres for å passe i den aktuelle kliniske konteksten. For eksempel: "Templat-overskrift" endret til "Funn ved undersøkelse", "Anamnese", "Personopplysninger" eller "Oppsummering".
nb.misuse: Skal ikke stå med uendret navn i en templat.

es-ar.purpose: Proporcionar un encabezado de sección de tipo genérico que será renombrado en una plantilla para su empleo en un contexto clínico específico.
es-ar.use: Utilizar para construir un encabezado de sección en una plantilla y que será renombrado para su empleo en un contexto clínico específico. Por ejemplo, "Encabezado ad hoc" puede renombrarse como "Hallazgos de examen".
es-ar.misuse: No debe mantenerse sin cambios en una plantilla.

pt-br.purpose: Oferecer um cabeçalho de uma sessão genérica que será renomeado no template para adequar-se a um contexto clínico específico.
pt-br.use: Utilize para construir um cabeçalho de uma sessão (de um template) que será renomeada para adequar-se a um contexto clínico específico. Por exemplo: "cabeçalho Ad hoc" renomeado para "Achados de exame".
pt-br.misuse: Não deve manter a configuração original no template.

en.purpose: To develop a short, psychometrically robust and responsive cataract patient reported outcome measure suitable for use in high-volume surgical environments.
en.use: Used by patients to record answers to six questions relating to vision and quality of life with cataract.

at0000.description: A brief psychometrically robust self-report questionnaire instrument for cataract surgery.

at0002.description: A specific date and/or time which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

at0004.description: @ internal @

at0006.description: Patient reported vision assessment in 'bad eye' during the past month.
at0006.comment: In the past month, have you felt that your bad eye is affecting or interfering with your vision overall?

at0007.description: The patient stated that their bad eye has not affected their vision overall.

at0008.description: The patient stated that their bad eye affected vision some of the time.

at0009.description: The patient stated that their bad eye affected vision most of the time.

at0010.description: The patient stated that their bad eye affected vision all of the time.

at0011.description: Patient reported how their eyesight has made them feel in the past month.
at0011.comment:
In the past month
How much has your eyesight interfered with your life in general?

at0012.description: The patient stated that their eyesight has not interfered with their life in general.

at0013.description: The patient stated that their eyesight has hardly interfered with their life in general.

at0014.description: The patient stated that their eyesight had interfered a little with their life in general.

at0015.description: The patient stated that their eyesight had interfered a fair amount with their life in general.

at0016.description: Patient reported vision overall assessment during the past month.
at0016.comment: How would you describe your vision overall in the past month - with both eyes open, wearing glasses or contact lenses if you usually do?

at0017.description: The patient stated that their vision was excellent in the past month.

at0018.description: The patient stated that their vision was very good in the past month.

at0019.description: The patient stated that their vision was quite good in the past month.

at0020.description: The patient stated that their vision was average in the past month.

at0021.description: Patient reported their vision had prevented them from doing things they like to do during the past month.
at0021.comment: In the past month, how often has your eyesight prevented you from doing the things you would like to do?

at0022.description: The patient stated that their vision had never prevented them from doing the things they like to do.

at0023.description: The patient stated that their vision had prevented them from doing the things they like to do some of the time.

at0024.description: The patient stated that their vision had prevented them from doing the things they like to do most of the time.

at0025.description: The patient stated that their vision had prevented them from doing the things they like to do all of the time.

at0026.description: Patient reported reading difficulty during the past month.
at0026.comment: In the past month, have you had difficulty reading normal print in books or newspapers because of trouble with your eyesight?

at0028.description: The patient stated that they had a little difficulty reading in the past month.

at0031.description: Record of who completed the results of the questionnaire.
at0031.comment: Please tell us who actually gave the answers to the questions and who wrote them down.

at0035.text: A friend or relative gave some of the answers on my behalf
at0035.description: The assessment was completed by a third party.

at0036.description: The patient stated that their eyesight had interfered a lot with their life in general.

at0037.description: The patient stated that their eyesight had interfered an extremely large amount with their life in general.

at0038.description: The patient stated that their vision was quite poor in the past month.

at0039.description: The patient stated that their vision was very poor in the past month.

at0040.description: The patient stated that their vision was appalling in the past month.

at0041.text: I cannot read any more because of my eyesight
at0041.description: The patient stated that they cannot read any more due to their eye site.

at0042.text: I cannot read because of other reasons
at0042.description: The patient stated that they cannot read any more due to other reasons.

at0043.description: The total score of the six questions.

en.purpose: To record the results of the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) and its subset assessment PHQ-2.
en.use:
Use to record the results of the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) and its subset assessment PHQ-2.

The archetype has been designed such that the actual PHQ questions are recorded as the description for each questionnaire data element. The data element name is a pragmatic description that is indicative of the question intent.

The original PHQ‐9 tool was developed by Drs. Robert L. Spitzer, Janet B.W. Williams, Kurt Kroenke and colleagues, with an educational grant from Pfizer Inc. From the PHQ Screeners website (http://www.phqscreeners.com/overview.aspx): "All PHQ, GAD-7 screeners and translations are downloadable from this website and no permission is required to reproduce, translate, display or distribute them." And from the PHQ webpage (http://www.phqscreeners.com/pdfs/01_PHQ/English.pdf): "No permission required to reproduce, translate, display or distribute". 

The Australian indigenous adaptation for the PHQ-9 subset assessing mood was developed by Dr. Alex Brown, Baker IDI Heart and Diabetes Institute, Alice Springs, 2009. The adapted questions are expressed within the Comments area for each questionnaire data element. Used with permission.

at0000.description: Screening questionnaire for mental health that can be used by health professionals or self-reported by individuals.

at0002.description: A specific date and/or time which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

at0004.description: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by little interest or pleasure in doing things?
at0004.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you been feeling slack, not wanted to do anything?"

at0005.description: The topic of the question has not affected the subject at all during the last two weeks.

at0006.description: The topic of the question has affected the subject on several days during the last two weeks.

at0007.description: The topic of the question has affected the subject more than half the days during the last two weeks.

at0008.description: The topic of the question has affected the subject nearly every day during the last two weeks.

at0009.description: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by feeling down, depressed, or hopeless?
at0009.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you been feeling unhappy, depressed, really no good, that your spirit was sad?"

at0010.description: Total score for the first two questions on 'Interest/Pleasure' and 'Feeling Down'.

at0011.description: Total Score for all nine questions.

at0012.description: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much?
at0012.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you found it hard to sleep at night, or had other problems with sleeping?"

at0013.description: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by feeling tired or having little energy?
at0013.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you felt tired or weak, that you have no energy?"

at0014.description: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by poor appetite or overeating?
at0014.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you not felt like eating much even when there was food around, or have you been eating too much food?"

at0015.description: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by feeling bad about yourself — or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down?
at0015.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you been feeling bad about yourself, that you are useless, no good, that you have let your family down?

at0016.description: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television?
at0016.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you felt like you can't think straight or clearly, its hard to learn new things or concentrate?"

at0017.description: Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered by moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed? Or the opposite — being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual?
at0017.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you been talking slowly or moving around really slow, or have you felt that you can't sit still; you keep moving around too much?"

at0018.description:
Over the last two weeks, how often have you been bothered 
by thoughts that you would be better off dead or of hurting yourself in some way?
at0018.comment: Adapted for Australian indigenous use: "Have you beenthinking about hurting yourself or killing yourself?

at0019.description: If you checked off any problems on this questionnaire, how difficult have these problems made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people?

at0020.description: The individual found no difficulty working, taking care of things at home or getting along with other people.

at0021.description: The individual found it somewhat difficult to work, take care of things at home or get along with other people.

at0022.description: The individual found it very difficult to work, take care of things at home or get along with other people.

at0023.description: The individual found it extremely difficult to work, take care of things at home or get along with other people.

de.purpose: Eine generische Abschnittsüberschrift eines Templates, welche entsprechend dem spezifischen klinischen Kontext umbenannt werden sollte.

de.misuse: Die Überschrift sollte in einem Template nicht unverändert verwendet werden.

en.purpose: To record information captured by the howRU™patient-reported outcomes instrument.
en.use:
'howRU' (TM) is a generic patient-reported outcomes instrument, designed to meet these requirements, and answer the central question: "How are you today?"
 It has four dimensions, which reflect the presence or absence of what matters most to patients, in addition to survival:
- Symptoms such as pain ­ includes discomfort such as breathlessness or nausea
- Feeling low or worried ­ includes anxiety, depression and fatigue.
- Limits to what you can do ­ includes physical incapacity, loss of memory, sight or hearing.
- Dependence on others ­ reliance on other people or equipment.

For each dimension, the patient picks one of four levels, indicated using a traffic-light metaphor with labels, colour, position and images. 
The four dimensions and four levels give 256 (44) different permutations, each of which represents a different health state. For data storage and analysis, each level is recorded on a 0-3 ordinal scale, with none = 3, slight = 2 quite a lot = 1, and extreme = 0. Higher score means better health. A simple aggregate howRU score is calculated by adding the scores for each dimension, giving a range from 12 (4 x none, ceiling) to 0 (4 x extreme, floor).

Copyright 2008 Routine Health Outcomes Ltd. All rights reserved. Used with Permission. Users should notify Tim Benson by email: timbenson@routinehealthoutcomes.com
en.misuse:
Should not be used other than to record information derived from the patient-reported outcomes instrument. 
Copyright 2008 Routine Health Outcomes Ltd. All rights reserved - Do not use without permission.
